description:
Bifidobacterium indicum is a species of Gram-positive, anaerobic, and non-spore-forming bacteria. It belongs to the genus Bifidobacterium, which is a group of bacteria commonly found in the gastrointestinal tract of humans and other mammals.

Bifidobacterium indicum was first isolated from the feces of Indian infants. It is a commensal bacterium, meaning it typically lives in harmony with its host without causing any harm. This species is known to be a member of the human gut microbiome and plays a role in maintaining a healthy digestive system.

Bifidobacterium indicum is characterized by its distinctive rod-shaped morphology and its ability to ferment various carbohydrates, producing lactic acid and acetic acid as the primary end products. This metabolic activity contributes to the overall gut health and the maintenance of a balanced gut microbiome.

Research on Bifidobacterium indicum is ongoing, as scientists continue to explore its potential health benefits, interactions with other gut microbes, and its role in human physiology and disease prevention.
prompt: Provide a short scientific description of this species: Bifidobacterium indicum
